user_request: A poem for Valentine's Day about true love lasting forever.
final_poem:
# Two Hearts, One River

There was a boy and there was a well,
and the well had watered everything he loved—
the dogwood in April, the creek in August,
each drought-bent blade of grass
curving back toward health on his word alone.

She did not ask for this. She only turned
when dust got in her eye, only knelt
to press a weed from the boy's shirt.
But he had already mapped her tolerance
on a kind of topography,
had named the elevation where trust lived:

a hill he could climb backward down at any time.

Years later: the well went dry.
Not all at once—there were seasons
where neither spoke of thirst, where pipes
rusticked deep in limestone, where no one
could say exactly when the water left.

And here is the miracle no one taught them:
that not possessing each other's history
made it possible for them to own
the whole beautiful property of now.
The boy stopped guaranteeing rain. The woman
stopped depending on his calendar.
They learned the landscape looked different
from either hilltop, that standing close
on the riverbank they could finally see
how their two streams converged into one
before entering into anything called Love,
which had been sitting there all along,
mud-colored and mineral-rich, untouched,

and both of them older now,
more honest about what they needed,
less interested in being right,
thinner than ever—open
like the valley floor where nothing grows
except the honest air.

This is how it looks. Not with cards or gemstones.
Not with any ritual. Just two people
standing in a field no one taught them to love,
tasting limestone, agreeing it's bad for teeth,
and not hating it for it.
